content.title: Economic Growth
content.definition: The sustained increase in real GDP or real GDP per capita over time, representing an expansion in the productive capacity of an economy and typically associated with improvements in living standards, technological advancement, and structural economic transformation.
key_points: Economic growth measures expansion of real output (inflation-adjusted GDP)
Per capita growth accounts for population changes: real GDP per person
Sources: capital accumulation, labor force growth, technological progress (TFP)
Solow model: Y = A × F(K, L) where A is technology, K capital, L labor
Sustained growth requires productivity improvements, not just input increases
Growth ≠ development: must consider income distribution, health, education
Environmental constraints: sustainable growth balances output with ecological limits

examples.title: British Industrial Revolution (1760-1840): The First Modern Growth Experience
examples.scenario: Between 1760 and 1840, Britain experienced the world's first sustained episode of modern economic growth. Real GDP per capita grew from approximately £1,250 to £2,330 (in 1990 international dollars), representing an 86% increase over 80 years. This transformed Britain from an agricultural society to an industrial powerhouse.
learning_objectives: Understand historical origins of sustained economic growth
Identify technological and institutional drivers of growth
Calculate long-run growth rates and doubling times
Recognize structural transformation accompanying growth
required_knowledge: Distinction between level changes and growth rates

quantitative_data.doubling_time: Rule of 70: 70/0.78 ≈ 90 years to double income

solution.step_3: Interpret: 0.78% may seem small, but compounds to transform society over generations
solution.step_4: Identify drivers: Steam engine (Watt, 1765), mechanized textiles (Arkwright spinning frame), iron production (coke smelting), railways (1825+), coal energy
solution.step_5: Structural change: Population shifted from farms to factories; urbanization accelerated; new social classes emerged (industrial bourgeoisie, urban proletariat)
solution.step_6: Institutional factors: Property rights, patent system (1624 Statute of Monopolies), relatively free markets, access to colonial resources and markets

common_errors: Confusing GDP level with growth rate (86% is cumulative, not annual)
Ignoring population growth (total GDP rose faster than per capita)
Assuming immediate transformation (took 80+ years of sustained growth)
Overlooking social costs (child labor, pollution, inequality initially worsened)
examples.teaching_notes: Emphasize: (1) even 'modest' 0.78% annual growth transforms economies over long periods via compounding, (2) technological change (steam power) combined with institutional change (property rights, markets), (3) growth came with significant social disruption and inequality, (4) this was unprecedented—no prior civilization achieved sustained per capita growth. Extension: compare to Malthusian era (pre-1760) where income gains were eaten by population growth.
variations: Compare British growth to contemporary China (10%/year) to show acceleration
Calculate how long for Africa (1.5%/year) to reach Western income levels
Analyze why Industrial Revolution occurred in Britain vs elsewhere (Belgium, France lagged)
visualization_suggestions: Line chart: UK GDP per capita 1270-1870 showing hockey stick acceleration post-1760
Bar chart: Sectoral employment shares (agriculture, manufacturing, services) 1760 vs 1840
World map: GDP per capita levels in 1840 showing British lead

examples.title: East Asian Miracle (1960-1990): Fastest Growth in History
examples.scenario: The 'Four Asian Tigers' (South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore) achieved the fastest sustained economic growth in recorded history. South Korea's real GDP per capita grew from $1,105 in 1960 to $8,704 in 1990 (1990 int'l dollars), a 688% increase in 30 years—averaging 7.1% annual growth. This transformed Korea from war-torn poverty to OECD membership.
learning_objectives: Analyze sources of rapid catch-up growth
Distinguish factor accumulation from productivity growth
Evaluate role of export-oriented vs import-substitution strategies
Assess sustainability of high growth rates
required_knowledge: Solow growth accounting: Y = A × F(K, L)

quantitative_data.investment_rate: Gross capital formation rose from 10% of GDP (1960) to 37% (1990)

solution.step_2: Doubling time: 70/7.1 ≈ 10 years (income doubled every decade!)
solution.step_3: Growth accounting decomposition: ~3-4 percentage points from capital accumulation, ~1-2 points from labor (education), ~2-3 points from TFP (technology/efficiency)
solution.step_4: Policy drivers: Export-oriented industrialization (contrasts with Latin American import-substitution), massive investment in education (human capital), high savings rates (30-40% of GDP), activist industrial policy (targeting shipbuilding, electronics, autos), macroeconomic stability (low inflation)
solution.step_5: Institutional factors: Land reform (1950s) reduced inequality, meritocratic bureaucracy, strong developmental state, pragmatic policy experimentation
solution.step_6: External factors: Access to U.S. markets, technology transfer from Japan/West, Cold War geopolitical support

common_errors: Attributing all growth to 'free markets' (substantial state intervention via industrial policy)
Ignoring initial conditions (land reform created equity; destroyed feudal elite)
Assuming TFP gains alone (much growth from massive capital investment—'perspiration not inspiration' debate)
Missing sustainability issue (investment rates of 37% difficult to maintain indefinitely)
examples.teaching_notes: Key debate: Krugman (1994) argued Asian growth was 'input-driven' (factor accumulation) not 'productivity-driven' (TFP), suggesting limits to continued rapid growth. This sparked controversy. Evidence: TFP contribution varied (Singapore: low; Korea: moderate-high). By 2000s, Korean growth slowed to 4-5%/year as catch-up gains exhausted. Emphasize: (1) fastest catch-up in history shows institutions matter, (2) export orientation outperformed import-substitution, (3) equity (land reform) preceded growth, (4) can't sustain 7% forever—convergence to steady state.
variations: Compare to Latin America (similar income 1960, diverged by 1990)—why?
Analyze China post-1978: similar strategies, even faster growth (9.5%/year)
Examine Malaysia/Thailand: growth slowdown after 1997 Asian Financial Crisis
visualization_suggestions: Line chart: GDP per capita trajectories 1960-2020 for Tigers, Latin America, Sub-Saharan Africa (divergence)
Stacked bar: Growth accounting decomposition (capital, labor, TFP contributions)
Scatter plot: Investment rate vs growth rate (positive correlation, diminishing returns)

examples.title: Nordic Model (1970-2020): Growth with Equity
examples.scenario: The Nordic countries (Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Finland) achieved strong economic growth while maintaining low inequality and extensive welfare states. Sweden's GDP per capita grew from $18,685 (1970) to $43,533 (2020) in 1990 int'l dollars, averaging 1.7% annually, while maintaining a Gini coefficient under 0.28 (vs 0.40+ in US).
learning_objectives: Understand that growth and equity are not necessarily trade-offs
Analyze role of institutions (welfare state, labor market) in growth
Compare growth models (Nordic vs Anglo-American vs Asian)
required_knowledge: Gini coefficient (inequality measure: 0 = perfect equality, 1 = perfect inequality)

quantitative_data.labor_productivity: Nordic countries rank in global top 10
quantitative_data.innovation: Sweden: 73 patents per million population (2019); US: 52
quantitative_data.happiness: Nordic countries consistently rank top 5 in World Happiness Report

solution.step_2: Compare to US: US grew 1.9%/year 1970-2020 with higher inequality (Gini 0.41)
solution.step_3: Mechanism: High taxes (50-60% top marginal rates) fund education, healthcare, infrastructure → high human capital → high productivity
solution.step_4: Labor market: 'Flexicurity' model (easy firing + generous unemployment benefits + retraining) enables structural change
solution.step_5: Innovation: Strong R&D investment (3-4% of GDP), world-class universities, tech sectors (Ericsson, Nokia, Spotify)
solution.step_6: Social cohesion: Low inequality → high trust → cooperative labor relations → stable investment climate

common_errors: Assuming high taxes kill growth (Nordic model shows compatible with innovation/growth)
Confusing welfare state with low productivity (Nordics highly productive)
Ignoring initial conditions (small, homogeneous populations; different from US scale)
Missing recent challenges (immigration, aging, global tax competition)
examples.teaching_notes: The Nordic model challenges simple 'equity-efficiency trade-off' narrative. Key insight: well-designed institutions (universal healthcare, education, active labor market policies) can enhance both equity and efficiency. BUT: (1) model faces challenges from immigration (social cohesion under strain), (2) high taxes require broad political consensus, (3) small country size (5-10M population) limits external validity, (4) natural resource wealth helps (Norway's oil). Counter-example within Nordics: Denmark shifted right in 2000s, reduced welfare spending, still maintained growth—shows multiple paths. Extension: compare to US (higher growth, higher inequality) and ask: which is better? No objective answer—depends on social preferences.
variations: Analyze Norway separately (oil wealth distorts comparison)
Compare 1970-1990 vs 1990-2020 (growth slowdown, globalization pressures)
Examine if Nordic model scales to large diverse countries (debate: Bernie Sanders vs critics)
visualization_suggestions: Scatter plot: Growth rate vs Gini coefficient for OECD countries (Nordics in upper-left: high growth, low inequality)
Bar chart: Government spending % GDP across countries
Line chart: GDP per capita growth Nordics vs US vs OECD average 1970-2020

examples.title: China's Reform Era (1978-2020): Largest Poverty Reduction in History
examples.scenario: Following Deng Xiaoping's 1978 reforms, China achieved the fastest growth of any large economy in history. Real GDP per capita grew from $979 (1978) to $15,243 (2020) in 1990 int'l dollars—a 1,457% increase over 42 years, averaging 9.5% annually. This lifted 850 million people out of extreme poverty (World Bank definition: <$1.90/day).
learning_objectives: Analyze transition from centrally planned to market economy
Understand dual-track liberalization strategy
Evaluate costs and sustainability of ultra-rapid growth
Assess 'middle-income trap' risk
required_knowledge: Centrally planned economy vs market economy

quantitative_data.tfp_growth: Estimated 3-4 percentage points of 9.5% from TFP (rest from capital/labor)

solution.step_2: Doubling time: 70/9.5 ≈ 7.4 years (income doubled twice per generation!)
solution.step_3: Reform sequence: Agricultural de-collectivization (1978-84) → Special Economic Zones (1980) → Township-Village Enterprises (1980s) → State-owned enterprise reform (1990s) → WTO accession (2001) → private sector dominance (2000s)
solution.step_4: Dual-track system: Maintained state planning while allowing market prices to emerge alongside—gradual transition reduced disruption vs Soviet 'shock therapy'
solution.step_5: Growth drivers: Massive rural-urban labor reallocation (Lewis model: moving labor from low-productivity agriculture to high-productivity manufacturing), capital accumulation (investment 45% GDP), technology absorption from FDI and reverse engineering, export-led industrialization
solution.step_6: Costs: Environmental degradation (air/water pollution), rising inequality (Gini: 0.30 in 1980 → 0.47 in 2015), debt accumulation (total debt 280% GDP by 2020), authoritarian political system (repression, censorship)

common_errors: Attributing growth solely to 'free markets' (state played massive role: industrial policy, SOEs, land ownership)
Ignoring initial conditions (very low starting point in 1978; catch-up gains easier)
Assuming sustainability (growth slowing: 10% in 2010 → 6% in 2019 → 3% in 2022)
Overlooking institutional weaknesses (corruption, lack of rule of law, property rights insecurity)
examples.teaching_notes: China's growth is extraordinary but controversial. Key debates: (1) Can authoritarian capitalism sustain growth vs democratic capitalism (ongoing experiment)? (2) Middle-income trap risk: as wages rise, manufacturing moves to cheaper countries (Vietnam, Bangladesh); can China shift to services/innovation economy? (3) Debt overhang: credit-fueled investment may lead to financial crisis. (4) Replicability: unique features (massive population scale, diaspora networks, geopolitical timing) limit lessons for others. Emphasize: (1) fastest large-economy growth in history, (2) pragmatic gradual reform vs ideological shock therapy, (3) growth came with major social/environmental costs, (4) future uncertain as easy catch-up gains exhausted. Extension: compare to India (democracy, slower growth but perhaps more sustainable?).
variations: Analyze regional variation: Coastal provinces (Shanghai, Guangdong) vs interior (Xinjiang, Guizhou)
Compare 1978-2000 (9% growth, low inequality) vs 2000-2020 (10% growth, high inequality)
Examine sectoral shift: agriculture (28% GDP 1978 → 7% 2020) to services (24% → 54%)
visualization_suggestions: Line chart: China GDP per capita 1950-2020 with 1978 reform inflection point
Bar chart: Poverty headcount 1981 vs 2015 (850M reduction)
World map: Share of global manufacturing 1980 vs 2020 (China's rise)
Scatter plot: Provincial GDP per capita vs distance from coast (coastal advantage)

examples.title: Equatorial Guinea (1995-2020): Growth Without Development
examples.scenario: Equatorial Guinea discovered large offshore oil reserves in the mid-1990s, leading to explosive GDP growth. Real GDP per capita grew from $1,817 (1995) to $10,174 (2014) in 1990 int'l dollars—a 460% increase in 19 years (9.3%/year). However, human development indicators barely improved: literacy remained ~95%, infant mortality stayed high (65 per 1,000 live births), and poverty persisted with 76% living under $5.50/day.
learning_objectives: Distinguish economic growth from economic development
Understand resource curse phenomenon
Recognize importance of institutions and governance
Evaluate Human Development Index (HDI) vs GDP
required_knowledge: Governance and corruption impact on development

solution.step_2: Compare GDP growth to HDI: GDP per capita rose 460% but HDI improved only 0.466 (1995) → 0.596 (2019)—modest gain
solution.step_3: Identify problem: Oil wealth concentrated in ruling elite; President Obiang family controls oil revenues; minimal investment in education, healthcare, infrastructure for general population
solution.step_4: Resource curse mechanisms: Dutch disease (oil boom appreciated currency, killed non-oil exports like cocoa, coffee), rent-seeking (bribes and patronage replace productive entrepreneurship), weak institutions (oil revenues fund authoritarian regime, no accountability)
solution.step_5: Development failures: Despite GDP growth, 76% still poor, health outcomes poor, education stagnant, economic diversification failed (90% GDP from oil)
solution.step_6: Vulnerability: Oil price decline post-2014 crashed GDP (down 32% by 2020); no alternative sectors developed; fiscal crisis

common_errors: Equating GDP growth with improved living standards (growth must translate to broad-based welfare gains)
Ignoring distributional issues (oil wealth captured by tiny elite, not population)
Assuming resource wealth automatically leads to development (requires good governance)
Missing sustainability (oil-dependent growth collapses when prices fall)
examples.teaching_notes: Equatorial Guinea is a textbook case of the resource curse and growth without development. Key lessons: (1) GDP measures production, not welfare distribution—need to examine poverty, health, education outcomes separately, (2) natural resources are a curse when institutions are weak (contrast: Norway managed oil well via sovereign wealth fund, democratic accountability; Equatorial Guinea did not), (3) diversification matters—oil dependence creates extreme vulnerability, (4) authoritarian regimes often fail to translate resource wealth into broad-based development. This example challenges the assumption that economic growth always improves lives. Extension: compare to Botswana (diamonds managed well via institutions) or Nigeria (oil curse, but democratic institutions eventually improved outcomes).
variations: Compare to Norway (oil-rich, high HDI) vs Angola (oil-rich, low HDI)—governance matters
Analyze Venezuela (oil boom 1970s, then collapse; similar pattern)
Examine UAE/Saudi Arabia (oil wealth, but higher HDI due to investment in services/infrastructure)
visualization_suggestions: Dual-axis chart: GDP per capita (rising) vs poverty rate (flat) 1995-2020
Bar chart: EQ Guinea vs regional averages for literacy, infant mortality, life expectancy
Scatter plot: Natural resource dependence vs HDI rank for developing countries (negative correlation)

examples.title: India's Jobless Growth (2004-2019): Output Without Employment
examples.scenario: India experienced rapid GDP growth from 2004-2019, averaging 7.2% annually, making it one of the world's fastest-growing major economies. However, employment growth was only 1.5% annually, and the share of workforce in formal employment actually declined from 11% (2004) to 9% (2017). Youth unemployment reached 23% (2019). This 'jobless growth' created social tensions despite strong GDP performance.
learning_objectives: Understand decoupling of output growth from employment growth
Analyze structural transformation challenges (premature deindustrialization)
Evaluate quality of growth (formal vs informal employment)
Assess implications for inclusive development

quantitative_data.agriculture_employment: 58% of workforce, only 14% of GDP (low productivity trap)

solution.step_1: Calculate employment-output gap: GDP grew 7.2%/yr but employment only 1.5%/yr → labor productivity grew 5.6%/yr (good) but job creation insufficient (bad)
solution.step_2: Identify problem: India needs ~10-12 million new jobs annually (demographic bulge: median age 28), but economy creating only ~4-5 million
solution.step_3: Sectoral analysis: Manufacturing (historically biggest formal job creator) stagnated at 15% GDP; Services grew but concentrated in high-skill IT (only 4M jobs) not low-skill (majority of workforce); Agriculture still employs 58% in low-productivity jobs
solution.step_4: Premature deindustrialization: India shifted from agriculture to services, bypassing manufacturing phase—unusual pattern. Services need high skills (IT) or are informal (street vendors); neither absorbs low-skilled rural migrants effectively
solution.step_5: Structural barriers: Labor laws make formal hiring costly (difficult to fire workers); small firms (90% employment) avoid formality to evade regulations; lack of infrastructure (ports, power) hampers manufacturing competitiveness vs China/Vietnam
solution.step_6: Social consequences: Youth frustration, underemployment (educated workers driving Uber), political instability, emigration of skilled workers

common_errors: Assuming GDP growth automatically creates jobs (depends on growth composition—capital-intensive vs labor-intensive sectors)
Ignoring informal sector (90% of employment; not captured well in official statistics)
Confusing labor productivity gains (good for living standards long-run) with job creation (needed short-run given demographics)
Missing institutional barriers (labor laws, land acquisition challenges, regulatory complexity)
examples.teaching_notes: India's jobless growth illustrates that HOW you grow matters, not just IF you grow. Key insights: (1) With massive labor force (580M by 2025), India needs labor-intensive growth sectors (textiles, light manufacturing), not capital-intensive (IT, heavy industry), (2) Premature deindustrialization: skipped manufacturing → services, unusual and problematic (manufacturing historically absorbed rural migrants in other countries), (3) Informal sector dominates (90%) but offers low wages, no benefits, no security, (4) Demographic dividend turns demographic curse if jobs don't materialize (youth bulge without employment → social unrest). Compare to China's path: manufacturing-led growth created 200M+ factory jobs 1990-2010. Extension: What reforms could shift India toward job-intensive growth? (Labor law reform, infrastructure investment, export-oriented manufacturing zones, vocational training). Also relevant: automation threat (will manufacturing ever create as many jobs as in China's era?).
variations: Compare to Bangladesh (slower GDP growth but higher formal employment growth in garments)
Analyze regional variation: Gujarat (manufacturing success) vs Bihar (stagnant)
Examine post-COVID trends: further acceleration of jobless growth?
visualization_suggestions: Dual-axis chart: GDP growth rate vs employment growth rate 2004-2019 (diverging lines)
Stacked bar: Employment by sector (agriculture, manufacturing, services) 2004 vs 2019
Line chart: Youth unemployment rate trend 2004-2019 (rising despite GDP growth)
Scatter plot: GDP growth vs job creation for major economies (India outlier)

examples.title: Silicon Valley & Tech-Driven Growth (1990-2020): Innovation and Productivity
examples.scenario: The San Francisco Bay Area (Silicon Valley) experienced extraordinary economic growth driven by technology innovation. Regional GDP per capita grew from $52,000 (1990) to $128,000 (2019) in current dollars, a 146% real increase (adjusting for inflation), while spawning globally dominant companies (Apple, Google, Facebook) and driving U.S. productivity growth in the 2000s.
learning_objectives: Understand role of innovation and R&D in modern growth
Analyze endogenous growth theory (ideas drive long-run growth)
Evaluate inequality implications of tech-driven growth
Assess spillovers and agglomeration effects

quantitative_data.real_growth: ~2.3% per year (1990-2019), above national avg of 1.8%
quantitative_data.venture_capital: Bay Area attracts 40% of U.S. VC funding (~$50B annually 2019)
quantitative_data.patent_intensity: 9,000 patents per million residents (2019; national avg: 850)
quantitative_data.r&d_spending: Bay Area firms spend $70B annually on R&D (2019)
quantitative_data.productivity_contribution: IT sector contributed ~1 percentage point to U.S. productivity growth 1995-2005
quantitative_data.inequality: Bay Area Gini coefficient: 0.49 (2019; national: 0.41); median home price: $1.3M

solution.step_1: Calculate real growth: Adjust nominal 146% increase for inflation (CPI rose ~80% 1990-2019) → real increase ~73%, or 1.9%/year per capita
solution.step_2: Attribute to innovation: Bay Area produces 9,000 patents per million (vs 850 nationally)—10x more innovation-intensive. R&D spending ($70B) generates new products/processes → TFP gains
solution.step_3: Mechanism—endogenous growth: Ideas are non-rivalrous (one person's use doesn't prevent another's) and have increasing returns (software scales at zero marginal cost). This drives sustained growth via innovation, not just capital accumulation
solution.step_4: Spillovers & agglomeration: Concentration of engineers, VCs, universities (Stanford, Berkeley) creates knowledge spillovers—'ideas in the air.' Workers learn from each other; talent attracts talent (positive feedback loop)
solution.step_5: National impact: Tech sector contributed ~1 percentage point to U.S. productivity growth 1995-2005 (Solow Paradox resolved: 'computers everywhere except productivity statistics' ended mid-1990s)
solution.step_6: Distributional effects: Tech workers earn $150K+ median; service workers $40K. Housing crisis (median home $1.3M). High inequality (Gini 0.49) and displacement of long-term residents

common_errors: Assuming all high-income is from tech (also finance, real estate); tech is ~15% Bay Area employment
Ignoring national slowdown: U.S. productivity growth slowed post-2005 despite continued tech innovation (Brynjolfsson 'productivity paradox 2.0'—why aren't AI/smartphones boosting GDP more?)
Missing housing supply constraints (zoning limits constrain growth; forces workers to expensive areas)
Overlooking winner-take-all dynamics (few tech hubs; hard to replicate elsewhere)
examples.teaching_notes: Silicon Valley illustrates endogenous growth theory: innovation and ideas drive long-run growth, not just capital/labor accumulation. Key insights: (1) R&D and human capital critical—Bay Area invests massively in both, (2) Increasing returns and network effects (software, platforms) create winner-take-all outcomes, (3) Agglomeration matters—concentration of talent/capital/institutions creates positive spillovers hard to replicate, (4) But distributional consequences severe: high inequality, housing crisis, displacement. Broader puzzle: if tech is so productive, why has U.S. national productivity growth slowed since 2005? Hypotheses: (a) measurement issues (consumer surplus from free apps not captured in GDP), (b) tech benefits concentrated in few sectors, (c) productivity gains offset by other sectors declining. Extension: Can other regions replicate Silicon Valley? Most attempts (Boston, Austin, Shenzhen) succeeded only partially—unique combination of Stanford, VC culture, permissive failure norms, immigrant talent hard to copy.
variations: Compare to Route 128 Boston (early tech hub, lost to Silicon Valley—why?)
Analyze Shenzhen, China (hardware-focused tech hub vs software-focused SV)
Examine post-2020: remote work reduces agglomeration benefits?
visualization_suggestions: Line chart: Bay Area GDP per capita vs U.S. average 1990-2019 (divergence)
Bar chart: Patent intensity (per capita) across U.S. metro areas
Scatter plot: Regional R&D spending vs income growth (positive correlation)
Map: U.S. venture capital concentration (Bay Area dominates)

content.statement: Economic growth—sustained increases in real GDP or real GDP per capita over time—is the primary driver of long-run improvements in material living standards. However, growth does not automatically translate into broad-based development; institutional quality, distributional equity, environmental sustainability, and employment patterns critically mediate whether growth improves human welfare.

explanation.intuition: Imagine a village that produces 100 loaves of bread per year. If it increases production to 110 loaves next year, that's 10% growth. If sustained over decades (compounding at even modest rates like 2-3% annually), the village transforms from subsistence to prosperity. Economic growth is the compounding of productive capacity over time—it's why we live vastly better than our great-grandparents despite being no more talented or hardworking.
explanation.key_insight: The power of compounding transforms economies: at 7% annual growth, income doubles every 10 years (Rule of 70). This explains China's rise (9.5%/year for 40 years → 35-fold increase) and why even modest 1.5-2% annual growth (typical of developed economies) makes each generation substantially richer than the last. However, growth's benefits depend crucially on institutional quality (corrupt regimes squander resource wealth), structural composition (manufacturing creates more jobs than capital-intensive extraction), and distribution (growth that only enriches elites leaves the majority behind). Growth is necessary but not sufficient for development.
explanation.technical_details: Growth accounting decomposes output growth (ΔY/Y) into contributions from capital (ΔK/K), labor (ΔL/L), and Total Factor Productivity (ΔA/A): ΔY/Y = α(ΔK/K) + (1-α)(ΔL/L) + ΔA/A, where α is capital's share (~0.33). TFP captures technological change and efficiency gains—the 'Solow residual.' Sustained growth requires TFP improvements; input accumulation alone faces diminishing returns (doubling capital doesn't double output). Endogenous growth models (Romer 1990) emphasize innovation: ideas are non-rivalrous and exhibit increasing returns, enabling perpetual growth. Empirically, cross-country regressions show institutions (rule of law, property rights), human capital (education), and openness (trade, FDI) strongly predict growth. The Solow model predicts conditional convergence: poor countries grow faster (catch-up effect) IF they have good institutions; unconditional convergence failed (Africa didn't catch up). Development accounting attributes cross-country income differences: ~50% from TFP, ~30% from physical capital, ~20% from human capital (Caselli 2005).

definitions_glossary.real_gdp: Gross Domestic Product adjusted for inflation; measures total output in constant prices
definitions_glossary.gdp_per_capita: Real GDP divided by population; measures average income/output per person
definitions_glossary.growth_rate: Percentage change in real GDP (or per capita GDP) from one period to the next
definitions_glossary.cagr: Compound Annual Growth Rate; geometric mean of annual growth rates over multiple years
definitions_glossary.total_factor_productivity: TFP; output growth not explained by input growth; reflects technology and efficiency
definitions_glossary.solow_residual: Another name for TFP; the residual in growth accounting after capital and labor contributions
definitions_glossary.capital_accumulation: Increase in physical capital stock (machinery, buildings, infrastructure) through investment
definitions_glossary.human_capital: Skills, knowledge, health embodied in workforce; enhanced through education and training
definitions_glossary.catch_up_growth: Rapid growth of poor countries converging toward rich country income levels
definitions_glossary.steady_state: Long-run equilibrium in Solow model where capital per worker is constant; growth driven only by TFP
definitions_glossary.rule_of_70: Doubling time (years) ≈ 70 / growth rate (%); e.g., at 2%/year, income doubles in 35 years
definitions_glossary.endogenous_growth: Models where long-run growth driven by internal factors (R&D, innovation) not exogenous technology
definitions_glossary.resource_curse: Paradox where natural resource wealth leads to poor growth/development due to weak institutions
definitions_glossary.dutch_disease: Resource boom appreciates currency, harming non-resource exports; part of resource curse
definitions_glossary.middle_income_trap: Difficulty for middle-income countries to transition to high-income due to rising wages
definitions_glossary.premature_deindustrialization: Shift from manufacturing to services at lower income than historical pattern
definitions_glossary.jobless_growth: Output growth without proportional employment growth; often due to capital-intensive sectors
definitions_glossary.inclusive_growth: Growth that is broad-based across society; reduces poverty and inequality
definitions_glossary.sustainable_growth: Growth that maintains environmental quality and natural capital for future generations
